signature_pattern: Few negative events in first half; no creature attacks before day 15; profit in top quartile; often first-time traders
common_trajectory: Uneventful early days -> good fortune continues -> success arrives without understanding why
notable_examples: Bagbu's third journey (year 871); Trader Ellum Vast (year 903)
lurra_notes: The Lucky Fool archetype is dangerous precisely because it feels like skill. These traders do not know what dangers they avoided.

signature_pattern: Distributed challenges throughout; multiple creature encounters, weather events, trade difficulties; none catastrophic; each resolved within 2 days
common_trajectory: Problem -> resolution -> problem -> resolution, steady throughout journey
notable_examples: Bagbu's hundred-and-twelfth journey (year 889); most experienced traders
lurra_notes: The Weathered Hand does not avoid problems - they face approximately the same number of challenges as other traders. They simply resolve them before compounding occurs.

signature_pattern: Few early problems (suggesting effective planning); cascade of failures in final third; careful preparation precedes sudden collapse
common_trajectory: Smooth sailing -> continued calm -> catastrophic failure in final days
notable_examples: Bagbu's seventy-eighth journey (year 885); Prime road washout victims (year 901)
lurra_notes: Preparation protects you from the known, and the known is not what kills you.

signature_pattern: Maximum event density in early days; chaotic signature with many events positive and negative; disaster creates opportunity
common_trajectory: Everything goes wrong -> continued chaos -> unexpected opportunity emerges from ruins
lurra_notes: The Happy Accident is not merely luck - it is the capacity to recognize opportunity within disaster. The same signature that destroys one trader creates conditions for another's success.

signature_pattern: Mixed signatures that do not fit the four primary archetypes; may show transitions between types
common_trajectory: Variable; some show hybrid patterns, others exhibit novel structures
lurra_notes: The archetypes are useful, not exhaustive. These journeys remind us that our categories are tools, not truths.

signature_pattern: Intense early activity (multiple projects, rapid advancement, recognition); sudden collapse (extended leave, voluntary demotion, or field exit) around years 7-9
common_trajectory: Years 1-3: Rapid success -> Years 4-6: Continued intensity with warning signs -> Years 7-9: Collapse -> Years 10+: Slow pace or exit
outcome_distribution: 25% return to high performance, 45% continue at reduced pace, 30% exit field
notable_examples: Coder TW-4471 (14 projects in 5 years, collapse in year 6)
lurra_notes: Burnout Arc collapses clustered at years 5, 7, and 11 - the yeller numbers. I have no explanation for this pattern.

signature_pattern: Steady progression with no early peaks; modest annual advancement; consistent but unremarkable output in early years
common_trajectory: Years 1-5: Entry-level, learning -> Years 6-10: Mid-level, consistent -> Years 11-15: Senior, expertise visible -> Years 15+: Peak productivity
outcome_distribution: 70% reach senior positions, 20% plateau at mid-level, 10% transition to other fields
notable_examples: Analyst KR-2208 (invisible for 12 years, dominant after)
lurra_notes: The Slow Climb is the most common archetype and often the most sustainable. Early invisibility predicts late dominance.

signature_pattern: Continuous educational activity; courses, certifications, workshops; few completed projects; rare promotions; limited practical recognition
common_trajectory: Years 1-3: Entry + heavy coursework -> Years 4-7: Continued education, changing specializations -> Years 8+: Extensive credentials, limited accomplishments
outcome_distribution: 15% breakthrough eventually, 60% continue pattern indefinitely, 25% transition to teaching/support roles
notable_examples: Builder PN-3392 (23 certifications across 4 specializations in 15 years)
lurra_notes: The archetype I find most troubling - perhaps because I recognize it in myself. There is always more to learn, and always a reason to delay.

signature_pattern: Chaotic early pattern (frequent job changes, mixed outcomes, no clear direction); unexpected specialization emerges from circumstance around years 6-8
common_trajectory: Years 1-5: Multiple jobs, no direction -> Years 6-8: Forced engagement with unexpected problem -> Years 9-12: Discovered expertise -> Years 12+: Recognized authority
outcome_distribution: 55% become recognized specialists, 30% find adjacent niches, 15% return to generalist pattern
notable_examples: Instrument maker VL-1056 (6 job changes, then atmospheric sensor innovation)
lurra_notes: The Accidental Expert parallels the Happy Accident in journeys - chaos yielding unexpected success. Specialization often emerges at years 7 and 11.

signature_pattern: Mixed signatures; may show archetype transitions (Burnout in first decade, Slow Climb in second); patterns not yet characterized
common_trajectory: Variable; some shift between archetypes, others show novel patterns
lurra_notes: Some workers shift between archetypes over time. The categories are approximate; lives are complex.

signature_pattern: Lucky Fool signature in experienced trader; early fortune despite evidence trader should know better
common_trajectory: Similar to Lucky Fool but with ironic awareness of risks avoided
notable_examples: Bagbu notes he was sometimes Lucky Fool even after years of experience
lurra_notes: Experienced traders can still be Lucky Fools. Wisdom does not prevent fortune.

signature_pattern: Weathered Hand signature with faster resolution times; problems addressed before they fully manifest
common_trajectory: Challenge anticipated -> preemptive response -> no disruption
lurra_notes: The highest form of the Weathered Hand - problems solved before they become events in the signature.

signature_pattern: Burnout Arc followed by extended recovery period; eventual return to sustainable productivity
common_trajectory: Classic Burnout -> Years of low activity -> Gradual rebuilding -> Sustainable late career
outcome_distribution: 45% reach original productivity, 40% find new equilibrium, 15% relapse
lurra_notes: Recovery from burnout is possible but rare. The second career is often different in character from the first.

signature_pattern: Clear transition between archetypes; often Burnout -> Slow Climb or Eternal Student -> Accidental Expert
common_trajectory: First archetype dominant years 1-10 -> Crisis or opportunity -> Second archetype emerges
notable_examples: Various; transitions at yeller number years
lurra_notes: People can change. The archetype is not a prison - unless we make it one.

signature_pattern: Deliberate avoidance of patterns; frequent changes designed to prevent classification; anti-pattern as pattern
common_trajectory: Varied deliberately; changes jobs, specializations, employers to avoid predictability
outcome_distribution: 35% successful by conventional measures, 40% unconventional success, 25% precarious
lurra_notes: The irony: deliberate pattern-avoidance is itself a pattern. Meck Drune is classifiable precisely by their refusal to be classified.

signature_pattern: Deliberate route changes, unpredictable timing, varied goods; designed to prevent pattern detection
common_trajectory: Unpredictable by design; no two journeys similar
lurra_notes: Meck Drune varies their routes, goods, companions to prevent pattern detection. The refusal is the pattern.

signature_pattern: Genuinely resists classification; no archetype fits; behavior unpredictable even in retrospect
lurra_notes: Some individuals genuinely resist classification. Jackson was not following a pattern we have not discovered - he was not following a pattern at all. This is the limit I could not articulate.

signature_pattern: Genuinely resists classification; events do not form coherent pattern
notable_examples: Rare; most journeys eventually fit some pattern
lurra_notes: Perhaps these are the journeys that teach us the most - the ones our tools cannot capture.

signature_pattern: Major career transitions at yeller number years (5, 7, 11, 13); suggests underlying rhythm
common_trajectory: Transitions clustered at prime years; stability between
outcome_distribution: Similar to base archetype; transitions are timing, not type
notable_examples: Various; pattern visible across all archetypes
lurra_notes: The yeller numbers appear in career timing as they do in creature behavior and journey events. I do not understand why, but the pattern is undeniable.
